explain: Sudo requires users to authenticate themselves, typically by entering their own password, before executing commands with elevated privileges. This ensures that only authorized users can gain root or other specified privileges.
Sudo uses the /etc/sudoers file to define which users or groups can run which commands as which users on which hosts. This fine-grained access control restricts the scope of privilege escalation.
Sudo can restrict which commands a user is allowed to execute with elevated privileges, preventing users from running arbitrary or dangerous commands as root.
Sudo logs all commands executed through it, including the user, command, and timestamp. This provides an audit trail for security monitoring and forensic analysis.

After successful authentication, Sudo caches the user's credentials for a configurable timeout period. This limits the window in which a user can run additional sudo commands without re-authenticating, reducing the risk of unauthorized use.
Sudo sanitizes and controls which environment variables are preserved or reset when running commands, preventing privilege escalation or attacks via malicious environment variables.
Sudo can enforce a secure PATH environment variable for commands run with elevated privileges, reducing the risk of executing malicious binaries from untrusted locations.
Sudo validates user input and can be configured to only allow specific commands or command arguments, reducing the risk of command injection or misuse.
Sudo can record the input and output of commands run through it, providing a detailed record of user actions for auditing and compliance.
Sudo supports security plugins, allowing administrators to extend or customize authentication, policy, and logging mechanisms to meet specific security requirements.
Sudo uses privilege separation techniques, running most of its code as a non-privileged user and only elevating privileges when necessary, reducing the risk of security vulnerabilities.
Sudo can integrate with SELinux or AppArmor, leveraging mandatory access control policies to further restrict what commands or resources can be accessed during sudo sessions.
Sudo can be configured to limit the number of password attempts, locking out users after repeated failures to prevent brute-force attacks.
Sudo can be configured to use LDAP or Active Directory for centralized user and policy management, improving security and consistency across systems.
Sudo can be configured to require or not require a password for specific users or commands, allowing for secure automation while minimizing unnecessary exposure.
Sudo allows specifying which user or group a command can be run as, not just root, providing more granular control over privilege delegation.
Sudo can restrict not only which commands can be run, but also which arguments can be passed to those commands, reducing the risk of abuse.
Sudo can be configured to require a TTY (terminal) for command execution, preventing automated or background processes from using sudo without user interaction.
Sudo uses the system's password hashing and encryption mechanisms to securely handle user credentials during authentication.
Sudo policies can be configured to allow or deny access based on the host from which the sudo command is run, providing an additional layer of security in multi-host environments.
